15 years ago,  Frances F. Denny (@francesfdenny) spent her first summer at Maine Media (@mainemedia) in Rockport, Maine. ‚ÄúSo many seeds were planted during those workshops, both from a technical perspective and from an artistic one,‚Äù she remembers. ‚ÄúIt was probably the most creatively generative two months of my life‚Äîand to be in magical mid-coast Maine‚Ä¶ Heaven.‚Äù
.
Over the decades, photographers including Arnold Newman, Mary Ellen Mark, and Ernst Haas have taught at Maine Media‚Äîon a campus surrounded by majestic mountains and sunlit blueberry fields. In celebration of their 50th anniversary, we spoke with Kari Wehrs, the Photography Program Chair at Maine Media, about the future. Hit the link in our bio to learn more.

My Childhood Pet (@mychildhoodpet) is a brand-new public art initiative created by Ellyn Kail, the editor of Feature Shoot, as a personal passion project. You can submit photos of your childhood pet by tagging #mychildhoodpet or @mychildhoodpet and including the name of the pet and the approximate date of the photograph. Old, strange, heartbreaking, or funny‚Äîall are welcome. Our childhood pets aren‚Äôt with us for very long, but they help to shape us into who we are.
.

Sirkhane Darkroom (@sirkhanedarkroom) is a mobile darkroom traveling through Turkey and teaching children‚Äîmany of them displaced‚Äîto tell their stories through photography. Now, they‚Äôre hosting workshops in Adiyaman and Kahramanmaras, two areas devastated by the earthquakes. Contribute to their vital work by donating at the link in our bio.

While casually browsing MPB the other day, we happened across the rare Canon 200mm f/1.8 lens, nicknamed the Eye of Sauron (slide 3). Only 8,000 of these stunners were ever produced, and they rarely crop up on online marketplaces. When they do, they usually cost $5,000+. Long story short: MPB has not one but two Eyes of Sauron in stock, as of this writing. One of them is listed for just $2,649. That‚Äôs not something you can find just anywhere. #MyMPB

‚ÄúAs I made these images, I was becoming aware that my body was remembering what it had gone through and was going through,‚Äù the photographer Veronica Cruz (@veronicacrruz) says. ‚ÄúBut I was also learning that it was okay to let it out and feel all of this without shame and without feeling like I had to hide it.‚Äù
.
In Little Earthquakes, the artist navigates childhood trauma through photography. Cruz was raped as a child. At the age of twelve, she had emergency brain surgery and was hospitalized due to an AVM, an abnormal connection between the arteries and veins in her brain.
.
Little Earthquakes is a work-in-progress, following the artist as she revisits the past and copes with the ongoing tremors reverberating in the aftermath of trauma. In some ways, the photographs represent an acknowledgment of the artist‚Äôs younger self‚Äîseen figuratively in an empty swing set.
.
Each time the artist herself appears throughout Little Earthquakes, whether she‚Äôs gazing directly at the camera or cradling her body, she reinforces the simple fact of her survival: she‚Äôs still here.
